g.text: 2.4. The Relationships Between IR and NIR Bands, and the Structural Features of Crystalline Melamine
Important conclusions may be drawn fromthe detailed comprehension of both IRand NIRspectra
of crystalline melamine. The vibrational modes involving out-of-plane atomic motions are much more
), and thus a proper reﬂection of the inter-plane structure
of crystalline melamine is required. Therefore, calculations that are based on a 3D inﬁnite model of
crystal lattice allows for the best description of these vibrations, even with harmonic approximation.
However, in the NIR spectrum the most inﬂuential modes are those that involve in-plane atomic
displacements. Thus, the neighboring planes of crystalline lattice do not impact these motions as much.
Therefore, the NIR modes calculated for a single molecule are largely enough to accurately reﬂect the
This also makes perfect sense by comparing the IR vibrations calculated in periodic system to
the ones calculated for a single molecule (also refer to Table S1 in Supporting Materials presenting
the potential energy distribution calculated for melamine). In the calculations that are based on a
single molecule (vs. the model of crystalline lattice), the out-of-plane deformation vibrations (e.g.,
ring) are positioned at higher calculated wavenumbers, while the in-plane
deformation vibrations are positioned at the lower calculated wavenumbers. Thus, the oscillators
with the out-of-plane atomic motions have lower calculated force constants because of neglecting
the surrounding crystalline planes. The neglecting of intra-plane interactions of melamine lead to
a surprisingly miniscule decrease of the accuracy of the calculated NIR modes. The corresponding
overestimated in the calculated frequencies, which was easily corrected by applying scaling. These
modes are seemingly less affected by the intermolecular interactions of melamine in crystal lattice,
2.5. New Insights on the Quantitative Analytical Spectroscopy of Melamine
Melamine is known food adulterant, and for this reason, it has been frequently focused on
]. After reproducing the spectra of melamine, we can more
deeply discuss some of the observations that were reported in these previous contributions.
NIR bands of melamine remain at relatively similar positions throughout various kinds of samples,
unlike its IR bands, which are prone to shifting in response to the chemical environment [
be fully confirmed by our conclusions from quantum mechanical calculations. Lu et al. [
reported that the most relevant spectral region of milk powder useful for the detection of melamine
. This region contains the binary and ternary combinations of NH
deformation modes of melamine; however, no overtone bands can be found there (Figure
] have found that the most meaningful region for the analysis of melamine content in
gelatin by IR spectroscopy is at around 800 cm
; the melamine bands therein stem from
). On the other hand, the chemometric models that are
based on NIR spectra of gelatin contaminated by melamine have been found to recognize the most the
region. The NIR bands of melamine due to the first overtones and binary combinations
of both symmetric and asymmetric NH
stretching modes can be exclusively found there (Figure
Our study allows for correcting Haughey et al. [
], who ascribed the NIR region of melamine in the
In more detail, the inﬂuential spectral regions in chemometric analysis of melamine content in
milk powders based on NIR spectroscopy has been reported by Lim et al. [
that the partial least squares regression (PLSR) models have recognized 6763 and 6808 cm
most meaningful in the analysis. They have concluded that these regions correspond to 6676 and
peaks of melamine observed in the spectrum of milk powder. We may now conﬁrm that
these two bands arise fromthe ﬁrst overtones and binary combinations of
of melamine, respectively. These previous chemometric analyses consistently indicate that for the
detection and quantiﬁcation of melamine, its NH
stretching vibrations are the most meaningful;
